item.title: Federal Prosecutors Open Investigation Into Fed Chair Powell
item.description: The investigation, which is said to center on renovations of the Federal Reserve’s headquarters in Washington, signals an escalation in the long-running clash between President Trump and the chair.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, left, and the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, right, touring the renovation site at the central bank’s headquarters in Washington in July.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Superstar’ Appellate Judges Have Voted 133 to 12 in His Favor
item.description: President Trump promised to fill the appeals courts with “my judges.” They have formed a nearly united phalanx to defend his agenda from legal challenges.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz, Emma Schartz and Alicia Parlapiano
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Threats and Venezuela Strike Leave Mexico Agonizing Over How to Respond
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum and her inner circle have been grappling with the right tone to strike in the country’s response to the Venezuela strike for fear of antagonizing the White House.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico has tried to thread a narrow diplomatic needle in the aftermath of the U.S. strike in Venezuela.

item.title: Trump Says Cuba Will No Longer Get ‘Oil or Money’ From Venezuela
item.description: President Trump urged Cuba to “make a deal, before it’s too late” in a social media post, but it was unclear what he meant. Cuba’s president responded with defiance.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Adalberto Roque/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators during a gathering in support of the Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro in Havana earlier this month. Mr. Maduro’s ousting was a blow to the strong relationship between Venezuela and Cuba.

item.title: As Death Toll Surges in Iran, Leaders Take Tough Line Against Protesters
item.description: Despite an internet blackout, reports are emerging of a rise in deadly violence as protests spurred by economic woes have snowballed into a mass movement.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran at a news conference in Tehran in 2024.

item.title: Deposed Shah’s Son Hopes Trump Will Put Iran Regime ‘Down for Good’
item.description: Reza Pahlavi, once the crown prince of Iran, says protesters there have been emboldened by President Trump suggesting that he could take military action.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joe Klamar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Austria displayed images of Reza Pahlavi during a rally on Sunday in support of nationwide protests in Iran.

item.title: Why Are Iranians Protesting? What to Know About the Unrest.
item.description: Demonstrations that began as outrage over the economy have spread across the country, amid an escalating crackdown by the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Leily Nikounazar, Farnaz Fassihi and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from a social media post on Friday shows demonstrators gathered in Tehran, Iran’s capital.

item.title: ‘Hundreds More’ Federal Agents to be Deployed to Minneapolis After ICE Shooting
item.description: The announcement by the homeland security secretary came days after an immigration officer shot and killed a woman, Renee Good, in the city.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, speaking during a press briefing in New York last week. Ms. Noem characterized the deployment of federal agents to Minneapolis as a mission “to uncover the true corruption and theft that has happened.”

item.title: Somalis Fled Civil War and Built a Community. Now They Are a Target.
item.description: A fraud scandal has made the Somali community in Minnesota a focus of the Trump administration’s crackdown on immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa, Campbell Robertson and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: In recent months, foot traffic and sales at Somali owned businesses in and around Karmel Mall have sharply declined following recent Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations in the area.

item.title: After Minnesota Shooting, ICE Again Limits Congressional Visits
item.description: The new guidelines for immigration facilities, issued by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, are virtually identical to a policy that a federal judge halted last month.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal immigration officials on Saturday used Kristi Noem’s guidance to deny Representatives Angie Craig, Ilhan Omar and Kelly Morrison, all Minnesota Democrats, from entering a detention facility in Minneapolis.

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Red Carpet: Nikki Glaser, Teyana Taylor, Jean Smart, Timothée Chalamet and More
item.description: Selena Gomez, Timothée Chalamet and the stars of “Heated Rivalry” were among the celebrities who arrived at the annual ceremony in high style.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Monica Schipper/Getty Images
item.media:description: Selena Gomez, a nominee, arrived in a Chanel gown.

item.title: Golden Globes Winners 2026: Full List Including ’One Battle After Another,’ ‘Sinners’ and ‘Adolescence’
item.description: The winning films, TV shows, actors and production teams at the 2026 Golden Globe Awards.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Rich Polk/Penske Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Chloé Zhao, center, accepting the award for best motion picture drama: “Hamnet.”

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Photos: Stars of ‘Hamnet,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and More
item.description: Our photographer is capturing behind-the-scenes moments with stars at Sunday night’s awards show.
item.dc:creator: Sinna Nasseri
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

item.title: Mayor Mamdani Is Moving On Up to Gracie Mansion
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani and his wife, Rama Duwaji, have begun moving their belongings from their Queens apartment to the official mayor’s residence in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gracie Mansion, the New York City mayor’s official residence, features security including a fence dotted with cameras.

item.title: Trump Wants Greenland — but He’s Not Alone in the Arctic Tug of War
item.description: For decades, an Arctic archipelago called Svalbard has served as a rare refuge of international cooperation. Those days are over.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Sarah Hurtes, Louise Krüger and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: A great power competition is intensifying in the Arctic, and not only for Greenland.

item.title: New Children’s Vaccine Schedule May Not Be the Last of RFK Jr.’s Big Changes
item.description: Comments by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his allies suggest the revised schedule may presage an approach to immunization that prizes individual autonomy and downplays scientific expertise.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family nurse practitioner in a white coat administers a vaccine to a three-year-old child in Seminole, Texas.

item.title: Schools in Occupied Ukraine Aim to Turn Children Into Russian Nationalists
item.description: Required lessons are heavy on militarism and pro-Russian, anti-Ukrainian propaganda. Some people make an arduous escape, partly to avoid the indoctrination.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana, 37, and her two daughters after crossing from Belarus into Ukraine, in December.

item.title: A Russian Videographer Reveals How Putin Shapes the Next Generation
item.description: Pavel Talankin was a school events coordinator and videographer. When Russia overhauled the curriculum to make students into patriotic soldiers, he kept his camera rolling. The footage became a film that is shortlisted for an Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m just standing there filming and I understand that what’s getting into the camera isn’t just a lesson, but history,” Pavel Talankin said.

item.title: Victoria and Michael Wolff Document Their Lifestyle in ‘Our Amagansett House’
item.description: The author and Trump antagonist Michael Wolff has his wife, Victoria, to thank for his latest chapter: lifestyle influencer. Now she’s becoming one, too.
item.dc:creator: Rory Satran
item.media:credit: Justin Kaneps for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victoria Wolff, the writer of Our Amagansett House, a Substack newsletter, at the home she shares with her husband, Michael Wolff.

item.title: Bob Weir Was the Dead’s Invisible Thread
item.description: The songwriter, guitarist and singer, who died at 78, animated the Grateful Dead from within.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Roger Ressmeyer/Corbis Historical, via Corbis/Vcg Via Getty Images
item.media:description: From left: Phil Lesh, Mickey Hart, Bill Kreutzmann, Bob Weir, Brent Mydland and Jerry Garcia.

item.title: Bob Weir: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The Grateful Dead guitarist, singer and songwriter was a bedrock of the band that became a psychedelic institution.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy

item.title: Bob Weir, a Virtuoso of Hot Pants
item.description: The Grateful Dead guitarist wore short shorts like no other.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Charles Steiner
item.media:description: Bob Weir’s shorts were short. They were snipped high enough that fans quite a distance from the stage could make out Mr. Weir’s upper thighs. Shy about skin he was not.

item.title: How a Puzzling 401(k) Plan Changed One Woman’s Life
item.description: Eryn Schultz was an H-E-B grocery store leader with an M.B.A. A slow pivot toward a big career change began when she found her retirement plan wanting.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eryn Schultz helped her grocery store co-workers understand the company 401(k) when she worked at H-E-B in Texas. Now she is a full-time professional financial adviser.

item.title: You Can’t Drone Strike a Global Drug Chain
item.description: Turning Latin America into a theater of war will not weaken transnational crime; it will entrench it.
item.dc:creator: Matias Spektor and Oto Montagner
item.media:credit: Illustration by Ricardo Tomás; source image by aleksandarvelasevic via Getty Images

item.title: A New World Is Taking Shape, No Matter What Trump Does
item.description: America’s days of unipolar supremacy are past.
item.dc:creator: Sarang Shidore

item.title: Avalanche in Washington State Kills 2
item.description: The men were among a group of four skiing in the backcountry near Longs Pass, east of Seattle in the Cascade Mountains. The area received heavy snowfall last week.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka

item.title: Famed Nigerian Author Blames Death of Toddler Son on Negligent Care
item.description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is accusing a private hospital in Lagos of administering an overdose of a sedative, prompting an outpouring of complaints by Nigerians about their health care system.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Schaun Champion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at her home in Maryland in February.

item.title: Once Again, Oldest Mississippi Synagogue Is Attacked With Fire
item.description: A suspect was in custody and charged with arson and accused of setting the Saturday morning fire. It’s not the first time the Beth Israel house of worship has been attacked.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao
